{{Infobox settlement |official_name = City of Torrance |settlement_type = [[City]] |motto = A Balanced City |nickname = T Town |image_skyline = torranceca.jpg |imagesize = |image_caption = View of Torrance Beach with neighboring [[Palos Verdes Estates, California|Palos Verdes]] in the background |image_flag = Torrance.gif |image_seal = Torrance seal.png |image_map = LA County Incorporated Areas Torrance highlighted.svg |mapsize = |map_caption = Location of Torrance in the County of Los Angeles |image_map1 = |mapsize1 = |map_caption1 = |subdivision_type = [[List of countries|Country]] |subdivision_name = [[United States]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Political divisions of the United States|State]] |subdivision_name1 = [[California]] |subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in California|County]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles]] |unit_pref=Imperial |government_type = [[Council-manager government|Council-Manager]] |leader_title = [[City Council]] |leader_name = Mayor Frank Scotto

Bill Sutherland | |leader_title1 = [[City Treasurer]] |leader_name1 = Dana Cortez| |leader_title2 = [[City Clerk]] |leader_name2 = Sue Herbers | |area_note = |established_title = Incorporated |established_date = May 12, 1921 |area_magnitude = | unit_pref =US | area_footnotes =[http://www.census.gov/geo/www/gazetteer/files/Gaz_places_national.txt U.S. Census] | area_total_sq_mi = 20.553 | area_land_sq_mi = 20.478 | area_water_sq_mi = 0.075 | area_total_km2 = 53.233 | area_land_km2 = 53.038 | area_water_km2 = 0.195 | area_water_percent = 0.37 | area_note = |elevation_m = 27 |elevation_ft = 89 |coordinates_display = inline,title |coordinates_type = region:US_type:city |latd = 33 |latm = 50 |lats = 5 |latNS = N |longd = 118 |longm = 20 |longs = 29 |longEW = W |population_as_of = 2010 |population_note = |population_total = 145438 | population_rank =[[List of cities in Los Angeles County, California|8th]] in Los Angeles County
[[List of largest California cities by population|36th]] in California
[[List of United States cities by population|166th]] in the United States |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |utc_offset = -8 |timezone_DST = PDT |utc_offset_DST = â7 | latitude = 33Â°50'5" N | longitude = 118Â°20'29" W |website = http://www.TorranceCA.gov |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 90501-90510 |area_code = [[Area code 310|310]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 06-80000 |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 1652802 |footnotes = }} '''Torrance''' is a [[city]] incorporated in 1921 and located in the [[South Bay, Los Angeles|South Bay]] (southwestern) region of [[Los Angeles County, California]], [[United States]]. Torrance has {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} of shore-front beaches on the [[Pacific Ocean]], quieter and less well-known by tourists than others on the [[Santa Monica Bay]], such as those of neighboring [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]] and [[Manhattan Beach, California|Manhattan Beach]]. Torrance enjoys a moderate year-round climate with warm temperatures, sea breezes, low humidity and an average rainfall of 12.55 inches per year.[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/889.htm City of Torrance Website: About Torrance] Retrieved 2009-04-07 The Torrance population was 145,438 at the 2010 census. This residential and light-high-tech industries city has 90,000 street trees and 30 city parks. Torrance is the birthplace of the [[American Youth Soccer Organization|AYSO â ''American Youth Soccer Organization'']]. ==History== Torrance was originally part of the [[Tongva people|Tongva]] [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] homeland for thousands of years. In 1784 the Spanish [[Ranchos of California|land grant]] for [[Rancho San Pedro]], in the upper [[Las Californias]] Province of [[New Spain]] and encompassing present day Torrance, was issued to [[Juan Jose Dominguez]] by [[King Carlos III]]âthe [[Spanish Empire]].[http://archives.csudh.edu:2006/cdm4/RanchoSanPedro.php The Rancho San Pedro Collection]Robert Cameron Gillingham, 1961, ''The Rancho San Pedro'', Cole Holinquist It was later divided in 1846 with Governor [[PÃ­o Pico]] granting [[Rancho de los Palos Verdes]] to JosÃ© Loreto and Juan Capistrano Sepulveda, in the [[Alta California]] territory of independent [[Mexico]].Ogden Hoffman, 1862, ''Reports of Land Cases Determined in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California'', Numa Hubert, San Francisco[http://content.cdlib.org/ark:/13030/hb9489p1s9/?&brand=oac DiseÃ±o del Rancho de los Palos Verdes] In the early 1900s, real estate developer [[Jared Sidney Torrance]] and other investors saw the value of creating a mixed [[Industry|industrial]]-[[residential]] community south of [[Los Angeles]]. They purchased part of an old Spanish land grant and hired landscape architect [[Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr.]] to design a new planned community.[http://www.hellotorrance.com/History.Cfm http://www.hellotorrance.com/History.Cfm] ''hellotorrance.com'' The resulting town was founded in October 1912 and named after Torrance. The city of Torrance was formally incorporated in May 1921.[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/8762.htm http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/8762.htm] ''ci.torrance.ca.us'' The first residential avenue created in Torrance was Gramercy and the second avenue was Andreo. Many of the house on these avenues turn 100 years of age in 2012. Both avenues are located in the area referred to as [[Old Town Torrance]]. This section of Torrance is under review to be classified as a [[historical district]].[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us] ''ci.torrance.ca.us'' Some of the early civic and residential buildings were designed by the renowned and innovative [[Southern California]] [[architect]] [[Irving Gill]], in his distinctive combining of [[Mission Revival Style architecture|Mission Revival]] and early [[Modern architecture|Modernist architecture]].http://torrancehistoricalsociety.org/ . accessed 8/28/2010 Historically the [[El Nido, Los Angeles County, California|El Nido]] neighborhood was home to many European immigrants, such as originally [[Dutch people|Dutch]], [[Germans|German]], [[Greeks|Greek]], [[Italians|Italian]] and [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] people; soon joined by [[Mexican-American]] and [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic and Latino]] immigrants; employed in the growing early 20th century agriculture, petroleum, and manufacturing industries, such as the fish canneries. {{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Rapid new growth in Torrance began after [[World War II]] as wartime industries transformed into [[Post-war]] [[Aerospace manufacturer]]s and related technology industries. Large housing developments were built in the 1950s and 1960s to accommodate the new population. Torrance moved on after the closure of some aerospace development and oil refinery plants in the 1990s statewide recession. {{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Torrance survived the deindustrialization, regional economic slowdowns and national recessions in the 1970s to 2000s. Large-scale [[Asian American|Asian]] immigration in the past couple of decades has transformed Torrance into a diverse and [[multiculturalism|multicultural]] city. ==Geography== Torrance is located at {{Coord|33|50|5|N|118|20|29|W|city}} (33.834815, â118.341330).{{GR|1}}. The [[United States Census Bureau]] boundaries show the city has a total area of {{convert|20.5|sqmi|km2}}, virtually all land. ===Description=== [[File:Torrance Beach.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Torrance Beach lies between the [[Palos Verdes]] Peninsula and [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo beach]] on the [[Santa Monica Bay]].]]Torrance is a coastal community in southwestern Los Angeles County, as seen on the map above, sharing the climate and geographical features common to the [[Greater Los Angeles area]]. Its boundaries are: Redondo Beach Boulevard and the cities of [[Lawndale, California|Lawndale]] and [[Gardena, California|Gardena]] to the north; [[Western Avenue (Los Angeles)|Western Avenue]] and the [[Harbor Gateway]] neighborhood of [[Los Angeles]] to the east; the [[Palos Verdes Hills]] with the cities of [[Lomita, California|Lomita]], [[Rolling Hills Estates, California|Rolling Hills Estates]] and [[Palos Verdes Estates, California|Palos Verdes Estates]] on the south; and the [[Pacific Ocean]] and city of [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]] to the west.{{cite web |url=http://www.surfline.com/reports/report_travel.cfm?id=4910 |title=Torrance Beach/Haggerty's |accessdate=2008-03-29 |year=2008 |work=Surfline }} Torrance Beach lies between [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]] and [[Malaga Cove]] on [[Santa Monica Bay]].{{cite web |url=http://skimonline.com/skim_spots/la.htm |title=Los Angeles County |accessdate=2008-03-29 |year=2007 |author=Peluso, Aaron |work=Skim Online |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071016103513/http://skimonline.com/skim_spots/la.htm |archivedate = 2007-10-16}} The southernmost stretch of Torrance Beach, on a cove at the northern end of the [[Palos Verdes]] peninsula, is known to locals as "[[Rat Beach]]." One of the country's few urban [[wetland]]s, the [[Madrona Marsh]], is found in Torrance to explore. It is a [[Nature reserve|nature preserve]], on land once set for oil production and saved development, with [[Restoration ecology|restoration]] projects enhancing the vital habitat for birds, wildlife, and [[native plant]]s.http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/6618.htm Madrona Marsh Wildlife Preserve & Nature Center websitehttp://www.insidesocal.com/history/2010/06/madrona-marsh.html History of Madrona Marsh. accessed 8/10/2010 A [[Nature center]] provides activities, information, and classes for school children and visitors of all ages.http://www.friendsofmadronamarsh.com/ Friends of Madrona Marsh Preserve . accessed 8/28/2010 Residents of an unincorporated area to the east of Harbor Gateway abutting the city of [[Carson, California|Carson]] are allowed to use "Torrance" in their addresses by the [[United States Postal Service|USPS]]. ==Torrance Attractions== [[File:USMC horses.JPG|thumb|right|150px|The Torrance [[Armed Forces Day]] Parade, with a [[USMC]] unit.]] The [[Del Amo Fashion Center]], at 2.5 million square feet (232,000 mÂ²), is one of the largest [[shopping mall|malls]] in the [[United States]]. Estimates vary between the second largest (after the [[Mall of America]]) and the fourth largest, depending on the measurements used. The current mall was created when Del Amo Center, built in 1958, merged with Del Amo Fashion Square, built in 1970. Once located on opposite sides of Carson Street, a gigantic expansion of the mall spanning Carson Street joined the two centers by 1982, making it the longest mall in the world at the time. In 2005, the east end of the original mall north of Carson Street was demolished to make way for a new open-air shopping center, opened in mid-September, 2006. The new center features upscale clothiers [[Anthropologie]], [[Coach, Inc.|Coach]], [[H&M]] and [[Urban Outfitters]] as well as the restaurant [[P. F. Chang's China Bistro|P.F. Chang's]]. The housewares retail giant [[Crate and Barrel|Crate & Barrel]] opened in what was once a section of the mall parking lot in Spring 2007. Torrance also borders the [[South Bay Galleria]], which resides in Redondo Beach. The [[Armed Forces Day]] Parade in Torrance, which was first produced in 1960, is the longest running military parade sponsored by a city. It is held annually on Armed Forces Day, and runs down Torrance Boulevard. The parade features military vehicles, school bands, and prominent community members.{{cite web |url=http://www.afspc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123020987 |title=Torrance celebrates Armed Forces Day |accessdate=2008-03-29 |author=Garges, Alicia |date=2006-05-31 |work=[[Air Force Space Command]] (US) }} The [http://www.torrnet.com/9009.htm Torrance Cultural Arts Center] hosts cultural events year-round. Regular performances are provided by the groups belonging to the [http://www.torranceperformingarts.com/ Torrance Performing Arts Consortium], including [[The Aerospace Players]], Los Cancioneros Master Chorale, South Bay Ballet, South Bay Conservatory, and The Torrance Symphony. Torrance is also home to the [http://www.southerncalifornialivesteamers.com Southern California Live Steamers Miniature Railroad]. located at the Southeast corner of Charles H. Wilson Park. Free train rides on actual miniature live steam trains are given on the first Sunday and third Saturday of each month and the 4th of July. SCLS was one of the first live steam clubs in California started in 1946 with original members like Walt Disney, Olie Johnston and Ward Kimball all of Disney fame. The club moved to Torrance in 1986 after leaving the Lomita Railway Museum property. ==City Parks== [[File:Wilson Park, Torrance.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Wilson Park, in Torrance at sunset.]] [[File:Madrona Marsh1.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Madrona Marsh]] Park, springtime in Torrance.]] The Torrance City Parks Department directs and maintains the thirty varied [http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/4715.htm Torrance City Parks].http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/4715.htm Torrance City Parks website . accessed 8/28/2010 They include: * [http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/9586.htm Wilson Park], the focal point {{convert|44|acre|km2}} park, which has extensive picnic and sports facilities, including a modern gymnasium, skatepark,[http://www.torrnet.com/Parks/7482.htm http://www.torrnet.com/Parks/7482.htm] ''torrnet.com'' and roller-hockey rink. Wilson Park also hosts the [http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/6620.htm Torrance Farmers Market] on Tuesdays and Saturdays, and is the site of the city's annual [[Independence Day (United States)|Fourth of July]] fireworks display. * [[Madrona Marsh|Madrona Marsh Wildlife Preserve & Nature Center]] is a rare Southern California [[wetland]]s [[habitat]] with higher [[Coastal sage scrub|Coastal sage]] [[Plant community|community]] [[California native plants|native plant]]s areas, wildlife and [[birdwatching]], and a [[Nature center]] with natural gardens classes â located centrally in the city.http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/6618.htm Madrona Marsh Wildlife Preserve & Nature Center website . accessed 8/28/2010 * [[Columbia Park, Torrance, California|Columbia Park]] the large recreational [[urban park|urban]] [[regional park]], with numerous picnic areas, field sports facilities, [[trail|walking path]]s, [[jogging]] trails, and a competitive [[cross country running]] racecourse.http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/4727.htm Official Columbia Park website . accessed 8/28/2010{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Ken|date=April 16, 2007|work=[[Daily Breeze]]|title=Ferraro left remarkable legacy|section=|pages=A10|accessdate=11 November 2008|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?&ArticleID=1189F9A48D6E4B20}} The city's [[Cherry blossom tree]] grove, part of Living Tree Dedication program, is in Columbia Park. *Torrance Smart Gardening Center: Columbia Park features a [[Community gardening|Community Garden]] providing planting beds and 'community' for residents. It is one of twelve county-operated [http://dpw.lacounty.gov/epd/sg/index.cfm Smart Gardening Centers] around the region.http://dpw.lacounty.gov/epd/sg/index.cfm L.A. County Smart Gardening Centers . accessed 8/28/2010{{cite news|last=Sandell|first=Scott|date=February 16, 1995|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=Highly Cultivated Community gardens tucked away in the landscape yield bushels of produce, offer an oasis from city life and provide fertile ground for social interaction|section=South Bay|page=8|accessdate=11 November 2008|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-02-16/news/cb-32553_1_community-gardens}}{{cite news|last=Fogel|first=|date=October 22, 2003|work=[[Daily Breeze]]|title=Torrance|section=Local|pages=A3|accessdate=11 November 2008|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?&ArticleID=0000917094}} Columbia Park additionally serves as home to the [http://dpw.lacounty.gov/epd/sg/map.cfm Home Garden Learning Center], and is a backyard [[compost]]ing demonstration center provided by [[Los Angeles County]].http://dpw.lacounty.gov/epd/sg/bc.cfm Smart Gardening: Backyard Composting Program . accessed 8/28/2010{{cite news|last=Walton|first=Stephanie|date=October 24, 2000|work=[[Daily Breeze]]|title=ASK US Q: Green waste recycling|section=Local|pages=B2|accessdate=11 November 2008|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?&ArticleID=0000803576}}http://dpw.lacounty.gov/epd/sg/map_graph/Columbia-Park-photo-L.jpg Torrance Garden Learning Center â photo . accessed 8/28/2010 *Living Tribute Trees park program: The Torrance Parks [http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/Documents/Living_Dedication_Tree_Program.pdf Living Dedication Tree Program] is coordinated and by the City, so that families, individuals, and groups can sponsor the planting of a new tree in the park to honor a person or commemorate an event with a living tribute Tree Dedication.http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/Parks/Documents/Living_Dedication_Tree_Program.pdf . accessed 8/18/2010 *Torrance Beach Park and [[Rat beach]], [[The Strand (bicycle path)|The Strand]], a paved bicycle path that runs mostly along the [[Pacific Ocean]] shoreline in [[Los Angeles County]], ends here. ==Climate== {{climate chart |Torrance |46|66|3.60 |48|67|3.22 |49|68|2.79 |51|71|0.73 |55|72|0.26 |58|75|0.08 |61|78|0.04 |62|79|0.13 |61|78|0.23 |57|75|0.48 |50|71|1.24 |46|67|1.99 |source=Weather.com / NWS |float=left |clear=left |units=imperial }} Torrance has a [[Mediterranean climate]] or Dry-Summer Subtropical ([[KÃ¶ppen climate classification]] ''Csb'' on the coast). The period of November through March is somewhat rainy, as shown in the table to left.www.weather.com The Los Angeles area is also subject to the phenomenon typical of a [[microclimate]]. As such, the temperatures can vary as much as 18Â°F (10Â°C) between inland areas and the coast, with a temperature gradient of over one degree per mile (1.6 km) from the coast inland. California has also a weather phenomenon called "[[June Gloom]] or May Gray", which sometimes brings overcast or foggy skies in the morning on the coast, followed by sunny skies by noon during late spring and early summer. ==Demographics== {{USCensusPop |1930 = 7271 |1940 = 9950 |1950 = 22241 |1960 = 100991 |1970 = 134968 |1980 = 129881 |1990 = 133107 |2000 = 137946 |2010 = 145438 }} ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]{{USCensus-2010CA}} reported that Torrance had a population of 145,438. The [[population density]] was 7,076.1 people per square mile (2,732.1/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Torrance was 74,333 (51.1%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 3,955 (2.7%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 554 (0.4%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 50,240 (34.5%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 530 (0.4%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 7,808 (5.4%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 8,018 (5.5%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 23,440 persons (16.1%). The Census reported that 144,292 people (99.2% of the population) lived in households, 506 (0.3%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 640 (0.4%) were institutionalized. There were 56,001 households, out of which 18,558 (33.1%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 29,754 (53.1%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 6,148 (11.0%) had a female householder with no husband present, 2,510 (4.5%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 2,152 (3.8%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 309 (0.6%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 14,472 households (25.8%) were made up of individuals and 5,611 (10.0%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.58. There were 38,412 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (68.6% of all households); the average family size was 3.14. The population was spread out with 31,831 people (21.9%) under the age of 18, 10,875 people (7.5%) aged 18 to 24, 38,296 people (26.3%) aged 25 to 44, 42,710 people (29.4%) aged 45 to 64, and 21,726 people (14.9%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 41.3 years. For every 100 females there were 94.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.8 males. There were 58,377 housing units at an average density of 2,840.3 per square mile (1,096.6/kmÂ²), of which 31,621 (56.5%) were owner-occupied, and 24,380 (43.5%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 0.8%; the rental vacancy rate was 5.3%. 85,308 people (58.7% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 58,984 people (40.6%) lived in rental housing units. ===2000=== As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 137,946 people, 54,542 households, and 36,270 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 6,715.7 inhabitants per square mile (2,593.1/kmÂ²). There were 55,967 housing units at an average density of 2,724.7 per square mile (1,052.0/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of the city was 59.16% [[Race (United States Census)|White]], 28.61% [[Race (United States Census)|Asian]], 2.19% [[Race (United States Census)|Black]] or [[Race (United States Census)|African American]], 0.41% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.35% [[Race (United States Census)|Pacific Islander]], 4.57% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 4.72% from two or more races. 12.79% of the population were [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Race (United States Census)|Latino]] of any race. There were 54,542 households out of which 31.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 52.1% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 10.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 33.5% were non-families. 27.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.1% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.51 and the average family size was 3.10. In the city the population was spread out with 23.0% under the age of 18, 6.8% from 18 to 24, 32.4% from 25 to 44, 23.8% from 45 to 64, and 14.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females there were 94.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.5 males. The median income for a household in the city was $76,312, and the median income for a family was $93,473.[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/STTable?_bm=y&-context=st&-qr_name=ACS_2008_1YR_G00_S1901&-ds_name=ACS_2008_1YR_G00_&-CONTEXT=st&-tree_id=307&-redoLog=false&-geo_id=16000US0680000&-format=&-_lang=en http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/STTable?_bm=y&-context=st&-qr_name=ACS_2008_1YR_G00_S1901&-ds_name=ACS_2008_1YR_G00_&-CONTEXT=st&-tree_id=307&-redoLog=false&-geo_id=16000US0680000&-format=&-_lang=en] ''factfinder.census.gov'' Males had a median income of $50,606 versus $36,334 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the city was $39,118. About 4.7% of families and 5.4% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 5.7% of those under age 18 and 7.4% of those age 65 or over. ==Economy== Torrance is home to the U.S. headquarters of two of the three largest [[Japan]]ese [[automaker]]s, [[Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., Inc.|Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A.]] (overseas office of [[Toyota]]), and [[American Honda Motor Company]]. [[Robinson Helicopter]]s are designed and built in Torrance as are [[Honeywell]]'s [[Garrett AiResearch|Garrett]] [[turbocharger]]s, used on [[automobile]] engines worldwide. [[Alcoa]] Fastening Systems is Headquartered in Torrance as well, producing aerospace fasteners. [[Pacific Sales]], [[PC Mall, Inc.|PC Mall]] and [[Pelican Products]] are among the other companies based in Torrance. According to the Cityâs 2009-10 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/PDF/2007-08_CAFR.pdf City of Torrance Finance Department 2007â08 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, p. 170] Retrieved 2009-04-06 the cityâs top 10 employers (and # of employees) are:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! Employer ! # of Employees |- | 1. | [[Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., Inc.|Toyota Motor Sales]] | 3,372 |- | 2. | [[American Honda Motor Company|American Honda]] | 2,196 |- | 3. | [[Honeywell]] | 1,163 |- | 4. | [[Robinson Helicopter Company|Robinson Helicopter]] | 1,107 |- | 5. | [[Lisi Group|Hi Shear Corporation]] | 1,000 |- | 6. | [[Alcoa]] Fastening Systems | 902 |- | 7. | [[L-3 Communications]] Electron Tech, Inc. | 673 |- | 8. | [[ExxonMobil]] | 674 |- | 9. | [[Pelican Products]] | 569 |- |10. | [[Adecco]] | 434 |} [[File:Del Amo palms.png|thumb|[[Del Amo Fashion Center]], one of the largest malls in the United States]] {{Refimprove section|date=December 2008}} As a major oil-producing region, Torrance was once dotted with thousands of [[oil wells]] and [[oil derrick]]s. Though the oil wells are not as common as they once were, the [[ExxonMobil]] [[refinery]] in the north end of the city is responsible for much of Southern California's gasoline supply. Torrance was also an important hub and shop site of the [[Pacific Electric Railway]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} Torrance has a busy [[general aviation]] airport, originally named simply "Torrance Airport" and since renamed [[Zamperini Field]] after local track star, World War II hero and Torrance High graduate [[Louis Zamperini]]. The airport handles approximately 175,000 annual take-offs and landings (473 per day http://flightaware.com/resources/airport/KTOA), down from the 1974 record of 428,000 operations. Airport noise abatement is a major local issue. In 2007 the [[Western Museum of Flight]] moved to Zamperini Field.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} Torrance is also home to the world headquarters of [[Sunrider]] International, as well as the U.S. Headquarters of numerous leading automotive aftermarket companies, including: [[Alpine Electronics]], [[Speed Star Racing Wheels]], [[Tanabe Racing Development]], [[Koyo]]{{dn|date=October 2011}} radiators, [[Stoptech]] brakes, [[Cosworth]], and [[Edelbrock]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} Torrance is also home to the main bakery facility for [[King's Hawaiian]], the dominant [[brand]] of [[Hawaii]]an [[bread]] in [[North America]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} [[Girl Distribution Company|Girl Skateboards]] and footwear companies [[Lakai Limited Footwear|Lakai]] and [[Globe International|Globe]] have headquarters in Torrance. Electronics manufacturer [[Panasonic]] has a plant manufacturing [[DVD-RAM]] and [[Blu-Ray]] media in Torrance. The United States division of Japanese videogame company [[Tecmo]] is also headquartered in Torrance. [[TabletKiosk]], manufacturer of Tablet PCs, UMPCs and Mobile Computing Accessories is headquartered in Torrance.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} ===Operations of foreign companies=== [[All Nippon Airways]] operates its United States headquarters, a customer relations and services office, in Suite 100 at Gramercy Plaza at 2050 West 190th Street in Torrance."[http://www.ana.co.jp/eng/flights/ticketoffices/northamerica/index.html ANA City Offices/Ticketing Offices North America/Hawaii/Guam]." ''[[All Nippon Airways]]''. Retrieved on December 22, 2008. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) raided the office on Thursday March 15, 2007; Laura Eimiller, the FBI spokesperson, did not say why the office was raided. The office resumed operations that afternoon."[http://articles.latimes.com/2007/mar/16/business/fi-briefs16.6 FBI raids U.S. offices of All Nippon Airways]." ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. March 16, 2007. C-4. Retrieved on February 2, 2009. The raid caused the carrier to not sell ticket reservations for several hours."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6457121.stm All Nippon Airways raided by FBI]." ''[[BBC]]''. Friday March 16, 2007. Retrieved on February 2, 2009. [[Aurora Publishing]], American subsidiary of Japanese publisher [[Ohzora Publishing]], is headquartered in Torrance."[http://www.aurora-publishing.com/contact.aspx Contact]." ''Aurora Publishing''. Retrieved on February 25, 2009. ==Government and infrastructure== ===Local government=== The City of Torrance is a Charter City. The original Torrance City Charter was voted on and ratified by the qualified electors at an election held August 20, 1946, and filed with the Secretary of State January 7, 1947. The elective officers of the City are the Mayor, six members of the City Council, five members of the Board of Education, the City Clerk and the City Treasurer.[http://municipalcodes.lexisnexis.com/codes/torrance/ City of Torrance Municipal Code] Retrieved 2009-04-04 Using the Council/Manager form of government, the City Council, as the elected body, adopts legislation, sets policy, adjudicates issues, and establishes the budget of the City. The municipality is supported by a general fund budget of about $160 million. The City Council appoints the City Manager and the City Attorney. According to the cityâs most recent Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the cityâs various funds had $192.7 million in Revenues, $167.3 million in expenditures, $179.1 million in total assets, $56.1 million in total liabilities, and $140.2 million in cash in investments.[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/PDF/2007-08_CAFR.pdf City of Torrance 2007â08 CAFR] Retrieved 2009-06-07 The structure of the management and coordination of city services is: [http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/PDF/2007-08_CAFR.pdf City of Torrance Website] retrieved 2009-06-04 {| class="wikitable" |- ! Department ! Director |- |City Manager |LeRoy Jackson |- |Assistant City Manager |Mary K. Giordano |- |Finance Director |Eric Tsao |- |City Attorney |John L. Fellows III |- |Police Chief |John J. Neu |- |Fire Chief |William Racowski |- |Community Development Director |Jeffery W. Gibson |- |General Services Director |Sheryl Ballew |- |Community Services Director |John Jones |- |Human Resources Director |Elaine Winer |- |Information Technology Director |Richard Shigaki |- |Public Works Director |Robert J. Beste |- |Transit Director |Kim Turner |} ====Commissions==== The city also has appointed Commissions to give residents a greater voice in local decisions. The Airport Commission advises the City Council on matters concerning the Torrance Airport. The Cable Television Advisory Board advises and makes recommendations in the area of policies and procedures in [[Public-access television]] [[cable TV]] interests, scheduling public-access programming, facilities, and equipment for the community and Public-access television channels, and disbursement of Foundation funds. The Civil Service Commission is responsible for all examinations for the original selection and promotion of city employees. The Commission on Aging deals with the needs and issues confronting senior citizens in the community. The Cultural Arts Commission assists the City Council in providing for and promoting opportunities for the artistic and cultural development of citizens. The Disaster Council conducts regular surveys of disaster readiness in the City and disseminates alert information to the public. The Environmental Quality Energy Conservation Commission deals with commercial sign reviews, oil production and oil site maintenance, animal control, beautification awards, community noise control, energy conservation, property nuisances, and property maintenance. The Library Commission makes recommendations regarding the operation of the library system. The Parks Recreation Commission advises and makes recommendations on matters pertinent to a public park and recreation program. The Planning Commission works with the Community Development Department in the preparation of master plans and zoning studies that affect the growth and development of Torrance. The Traffic Commission makes recommendations to the City Council on street and traffic improvement. The Water Commission makes recommendations for assuring high-quality non-interruptible water service at the lowest possible cost. The Youth Council is an advisory body to City Council on matters pertaining to youth in Torrance.[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/8752.htm City of Torrance Website: Boards and Commissions] Retrieved 2009-04-04 ====Postal Service==== The [[United States Postal Service]] operates the Torrance Post Office at 2510 Monterrey Street,"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/31996?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Torrance Post Office Location â TORRANCE]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. the Marcelina Post Office at 1433 Marcelina Avenue,"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/38079?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Torrance Post Office Location â MARCELINA]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. the Walteria Post Office at 4216 Pacific Coast Highway,"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/32289?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Torrance Post Office Location â WALTERIA]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. the North Torrance Post Office at 18080 Crenshaw Boulevard,"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/65468?p=2&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Torrance Post Office Location â NORTH TORRANCE]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. and the Del Amo Post Office at 291 Del Amo Fashion Square."[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/14833?p=1&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Torrance Post Office Location â DEL AMO]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008. ===Healthcare=== *Two major hospitals are located within the city â [[Torrance Memorial Medical Center]] and [[Little Company of Mary Hospital (Torrance)|Little Company of Mary Hospital]]. A third hospital, [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] [[Harbor-UCLA Medical Center]], lies just outside the city limits (in the [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] Los Angeles County community of West Carson) but also has a Torrance address."[http://www.ladhs.org/wps/portal/!ut/p/c1/04_SB8K8xLLM9MSSzPy8xBz9CP0os_hAFz8jl2AXYwN3F2dTAyMXLz9397BgIwN3Q6B8pFm8n79RqJuJp6GhhZmroYGRmYeJk0-YJ1C1MQHd4SD78OsHyRvgAI4G-n4e-bmp-gW5EQZZJo6KANdbijc!/dl2/d1/L0lDU0NTSUpKZ2tLQ2xFQSEvb01vUUFBSVFKQUFNWXhpbE1RWndYQk00L1lCSkp3NDU0NTAtNUY0a3N0eWp3LzdfUUROMkRTRDMwR0RDNTAyREpOR0dWUzIwMTQveElNZWg5NjkzMDAyMy9iZl9hY3Rpb24vSG9zcGl0YWxz/ Hospitals]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 17, 2010."[http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/MapItDrawServlet?geo_id=16000US0684144&_bucket_id=50&tree_id=420&context=saff&_lang=en&_sse=on West Carson CDP, California]." [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on March 17, 2010. [[HealthCare Partners|HealthCare Partners Medical Group]]'s corporate headquarters is in Torrance on Vermont Ave. HealthCare Partners is one California's largest medical groups.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the Torrance Health Center in [[Harbor Gateway, Los Angeles, California|Harbor Gateway]], [[Los Angeles]], serving Torrance."[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/torrance.pdf Torrance Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010. ===Emergency services=== * [[Torrance Fire Department]] staffs five paramedic rescue squads at Fire Station 1 (Headquarters), Fire Station 3, Fire Station 4, A new one at Fire Station 5 as of February, 2008, and Fire Station 6. Torrance Memorial Medical Center, Little Company of Mary Hospital, Harbor-UCLA Medical Center, Kaiser Hospital-South Bay, and Memorial Hospital of Gardena are receiving hospitals for residents in Torrance who call 911 for medical assistance. Ambulance transportation is provided through [[Gerber Ambulance Service]]. ===Public libraries=== The City of Torrance operates a main library facility (named after former mayor [[Katy Geissert]]) in the city Civic Center, plus five branches at locations throughout the city.[http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/5465.htm http://www.ci.torrance.ca.us/5465.htm] ''ci.torrance.ca.us'' ===Transportation=== Highways and freeways in the region include [[Interstate 110 (California)|I-110]], [[Interstate 405 (California)|I-405]], [[California State Route 91|SR 91]], [[California State Route 107|SR 107]], and [[California State Route 1|SR 1]]. Rail transport includes the historic [[Harbor Subdivision]] which carries [[Union Pacific]] and [[BNSF Railway|BNSF]] lines. The city also has [[Torrance Transit]], [[Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority|LACMTA]] [[Metro Local|Metro bus]], and [[Los Angeles Department of Transportation|LADOT]] services. [[Zamperini Field]] ([[International Air Transport Association|IATA]]: TOA [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]]: KTOA) is a general aviation airport and serves no commercial airlines. However, Torrance is within 15 minutes of both [[Los Angeles International Airport]] and [[Long Beach Airport]]. ===Activities=== In the 2010 [[Tournament of Roses Parade|Rose Parade]], City of Torrance's entry won the top Lathrop K. Leishman trophy for its ''Garden of Dreams'' float, judged as the ''"Most Beautiful Non-Commercial"'' float. ==Politics== In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Torrance is located in the 28th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Ted Lieu]], and in the 53rd [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Betsy Butler]]. Federally, Torrance is located in [[California's 36th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +11{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}} and is represented by Democrat [[Janice Hahn]]. ==Education== ===Primary and secondary schools=== ====Public schools==== [[Torrance Unified School District]] (TUSD) was established as a school district in 1947 and unified in 1948. The district encompasses all of the City of Torrance, bordered by the Palos Verdes Peninsula on the south, the cities of Redondo Beach and Gardena on the north, the City of Carson on the east and the Pacific Ocean on the west. The district's jurisdiction includes approximately {{convert|21|sqmi|km2}}, and it operates 17 elementary schools, eight middle schools, five high schools (one of which is a continuation school), three adult education centers, and a child development center. [[File:TorranceHighSchool Doors.jpg|thumb|[[Torrance High School]] is one of the oldest high schools in California, having opened in 1917.[http://www.tusd.org/pages/uploaded_files/THS%20Profile%2008-09%20FINAL.pdf Torrance Unified School District website â About Torrance High] Retrieved 2009-04-08 {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Some families have attended Torrance High for generations.]] The Torrance Unified School District's five [[high school]]s are: * [[Torrance High School]] * [[North High School (Torrance)|North High School]] * [[South High School (Torrance)|South High School]] * [[West High School (Torrance)|West High School]] *Kurt Shery High School (continuation) Area districts have created the [[Southern California Regional Occupational Center]] (SCROC) to teach technical classes to their students and to local adults. TUSD is a participant feeder district of the [[California Academy of Mathematics and Science]] or CAMS, a mathematics and science magnet high school, administered by the [[Long Beach Unified School District]]. =====Private schools===== Two private high schools are also located in Torrance: * [[Bishop Montgomery High School]] (administered by the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles]]) * [[Pacific Lutheran High School]] Eight private elementary/middle schools are in Torrance: Ascension Lutheran School, Riviera Hall Lutheran School, Riviera Methodist School, South Bay Junior Academy, Nativity Catholic School, First Lutheran School, St James Catholic School and St Catherine Laboure Catholic School. ===Colleges and universities=== Torrance lies within the El Camino Community College District and [[El Camino College]] uses a Torrance mailing address, but the campus is actually located just outside the city limits in the unincorporated Los Angeles county area known as El Camino Village. El Camino College was founded in 1947, and the campus covers 126 acres. As of 2011, the college enrolls over 25,000 students each semester.[http://www.ElCamino.edu Reference] ==Media== The ''[[Daily Breeze]]'', a 70,000-circulation daily [[newspaper]], is published in Torrance. It serves the [[South Bay, Los Angeles|South Bay]] cities of [[Los Angeles County]]. Its slogan is "LAX to LA Harbor". Herald Publications, media group started the ''Torrance Tribune'', a community newspaper, which was started November 2010, it has a distribution of 15,000 newspapers to single-family homes and businesses in the City of Torrance, only. ==Sister cities== In 1973, Torrance established a sister-city relationship with [[Kashiwa, Chiba]], [[Japan]], as part of the [[Sister Cities International]] program. Since then, citizens of Torrance have regularly engaged in cultural exchange with Kashiwa through the guidance of the Torrance Sister City Association, which facilitates a Japanese cultural festival, a yearly student exchange program, and contact between officials of the two cities. [[North High School (Torrance)|North High]] is the official sister high school of Kashiwa Municipal High. ==Notable natives and residents== {{See also|Category:People from Torrance, California}} {{col-start}}{{col-break}} * [[Alyson Michalka|Alyson]] & [[Amanda Michalka]] ([[Aly & AJ]]) â Singers & actresses * [[AdÃ¡n SÃ¡nchez]] â Mexican American corrido singer * [[Amy Okuda]] â actress * [[Antonio Margarito]] â Mexican-American professional boxer * [[Ben Going]] â [[YouTube]] Celebrity * [[Bobby East]] â [[NASCAR]] driver * [[Bud Smith]] â Retired [[MLB]] player; threw a [[no-hitter]] in his rookie season (2001) * [[Brandon Manumaleuna]] â NFL tight end for Chicago Bears * [[Chad Morton]] â [[National Football League|NFL]] player * [[Chris Demaria]] â Former MLB pitcher for the [[Kansas City Royals|Royals]] and [[Milwaukee Brewers|Brewers]] * [[Chuck Norris]] â Karate expert; opened his first [[Dojo]] in Torrance * [[Daewon Song]] â Professional skateboarder * [[Daryl Sabara]] & [[Evan Sabara]] â Actors (''[[Spy Kids]]'' and ''[[Keeping Up with the Steins]]'') * [[David Wells]] â [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] pitcher, formerly with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] * [[Denzel Whitaker]] â Actor * [[Deon Thompson]] â [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina Tar Heels]] basketball player * [[Don Newcombe]] â Former [[Los Angeles Dodgers|LA Dodger]]; only winner of [[MLB Rookie of the Year award|Rookie of the Year]], [[MLB Most Valuable Player award|MVP]], and [[Cy Young Award|Cy Young]] awards * [[Francisco Mendoza]] â [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] player * [[Fred Kendall]] â Former [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] catcher and manager * [[Gina Hiraizumi]] - Actress, Recording Artist * [[George Nakano]] â California politician * [[Jack Stewart (soccer)|Jack Stewart]] â Soccer player, currently with the [[Carolina RailHawks]] in the [[USL First Division|USL-1]] * [[Jason "Wee-Man" AcuÃ±a]] â American TV host and actor * [[Jason Kendall]] â [[Kansas City Royals]] catcher * [[Harajuku Girls#Jennifer Kita|Jennifer Kita]]: Angel/Lil Angel of [[The Harajuku Girls]] * [[Joe Stevenson]] â [[Mixed martial arts]] practitioner and [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] fighter {{col-break}} * [[John Butler (musician)|John Butler]] â Leader of the [[John Butler Trio]] * [[Jimmy Briggs]] â Stand Up Comic * [[John G. Barrett]] â [[Martial arts|Martial artist]] and actor * [[John Chiang (California politician)|John Chiang]] â http://www.sco.ca.gov/eo_about_bio.html California State Controller * [[Johnnie Morton]] â [[National Football League|NFL]] player * [[Jonathan Bornstein]] - soccer left back/midfielder ([[UANL]] & national team) * [[Justin Conway]] â Total Jabroni * [[Justin Shenkarow]] â Actor * [[Justin Miller (baseball)|Justin Miller]] â [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] pitcher * [[Kevin Kim]] â Professional tennis player * [[Larry Carlton]] â Guitarist * [[Lisa Moretti]] â [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]]'s "Ivory" * [[Louis Zamperini]] â 1936 Olympic track star, World War II veteran, author (Devil At My Heels), speaker * [[Michael Dudikoff]] â Film actor * [[Mikel J. Hennessay]] â former NHRA Super Stock driver * [[Michelle Kwan]] â 5-time World Figure Skating Champion and Olympian * [[Parnelli Jones]] â [[United States Automobile Club|USAC]] driver and his son, [[P. J. Jones]] â [[Indy Racing League|IRL]] driver * [[Paul Moyer]] â Veteran television news broadcaster * [[Paul Westphal]] â retired [[NBA]] player and current head coach of the [[Sacramento Kings]] * [[Quentin Tarantino]] â Filmmaker * [[Roger Clinton, Jr.|Roger Clinton]] â Half-brother of President [[Bill Clinton]] * [[Rorion Gracie]] & [[Royce Gracie]] â [[Mixed martial arts]] practitioners and [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] fighters * [[Sean Hinkley]] â Japan Basketball National Team Member (Team B){{cite web|title=2011 Jones Cup roster|url=http://wjc.basketball-tpe.org/files/901-1004-87,c3.php|accessdate=20 September 2011}} and [[Link Tochigi Brex]] player in the [[Japanese Basketball League]]. * [[Skip Schumaker]] â [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] outfielder for the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] * [[Snoop Dogg]] â Rap artist, reportedly owns a mansion in Torrance {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} * [[Steve Sarkisian]] â [[University of Washington]] Head Football Coach * [[Stuart Lown]] - Owner and founder of Crazy Can * [[Ted Lilly]] â Starting pitcher for the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] * [[Tony Gonzalez (American football)|Tony Gonzalez]] â [[Tight end]] for the [[Atlanta Falcons]]; eleven time [[Pro Bowl]] selection {{col-end}} ===Media appearances=== The city has been subject of a number of cultural references. Mark Wahlberg is involved in two, in ''[[Boogie Nights]]'' his character Eddie Adams/Dirk Diggler is from Torrance, and in ''[[Three Kings (1999 film)|Three Kings]]'' his character Sfc. Troy Barlow in the epilogue is revealed to go on to manage a carpet store in Torrance, California. Coincidently, Three Kings co-star [[Spike Jonze]] directed a mocumentary chronicling the fictional Torrance Community Dance Group (from [[Fatboy Slim]]'s "[[Praise You]]" video, also directed by Jonze) on their road to the MTV Video Music Awards. Torrance is also mentioned in the South Park episode [[Freak Strike]]. Torrance was also a filming location for the 1997 film ''[[Volcano (1997 film)|Volcano]]''. Torrance Beach is mentioned in the 1994 comedy ''[[The Stoned Age]]''. Much of the film "Lifeguard" starring Sam Elliott was filmed on Torrance beach, with numerous scenes shot throughout the Torrance area. The [[Del Amo Fashion Center]] has been used as a location for several [[motion pictures]], including ''[[Jackie Brown (film)|Jackie Brown]]'' and ''[[Bad Santa]]''. The Torrance Drive-In, now gone, is the mentioned in chapter 8 of the [[Philip K. Dick]] novel, ''[[A Scanner Darkly]]''. [[Torrance High School]]'s facade is familiar to television viewers as the setting for ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'' and its spinoff, ''[[90210 (TV series)|90210]]'' and ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' and to filmgoers for its appearances in ''[[She's All That]]'', ''[[Not Another Teen Movie]]'' and ''[[The Wild Life (film)|The Wild Life]]''. [[South High School (Torrance)|South High School]], near the southern border of Torrance, was used as a location for the 1999 filming of the film ''[[American Beauty (film)|American Beauty]]''. Torrance is also the home of filming the hit show [[Zeke and Luther]]. They have appeared skateboarding at the [[Daily Breeze]] building, and Wilson Park. Torrrance Beach was a filming location in the Fox Television series ''[[The O.C.]]'' In Tony Hawk Pro Skater 2, School 2 references North High. ==Miscellaneous== {{Refimprove|date=June 2011}} In 1986 the [[United States men's national soccer team]] was in the last game of the qualifying tournament, the U.S. needed only a draw against [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], whom the U.S. had beaten 3â0 in the Olympics the year before, in order to reach the final qualification group against [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]] and [[Canada men's national soccer team|Canada]]. U.S. Soccer scheduled the game to be played at [[El Camino College]], an area with many [[Costa Rican American|Costa Rican]] expatriates, and marketed the game almost exclusively to the Costa Rican community, even providing Costa Rican folk dances as halftime entertainment.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/michael_lewis/news/2000/11/10/lewis_history/ |title=CNNSI.com â Inside Game â Michael Lewis â Offside Remarks â CNNSI.com's Lewis: Learning from history â Friday November 10, 2000 07:29 PM |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}} A 35th minute goal by [[Evaristo Coronado]] won the match for Costa Rica and kept the United States from reaching its fourth World Cup finals.http://us-soccer.com/secured/articles/viewArticle.jsp_3063.html In 1988, [[N.W.A.]] recorded ''[[Straight Outta Compton]]'' at Audio Achievements studio in Torrance. Torrance is also known for its [[multicultural]] [[Multiculturalism|diversity]] of [[East Asian]] and European ethnic groups, and even many [[Polynesians]], [[Indian American]]s, [[Arab American]]s and [[Persian American]]s. Some of the city's sections like El Nido, Moneta, Clifton along with [[Redondo Beach, California|Redondo Beach]] and Hollywood Riviera are examples of the [[ethnoburb]] phenomenon. Historically, local whites tolerated the presence of [[Japanese American]], [[Portuguese American]] and Mexican residents, but not much support for [[African American]]s to relocate in their neighborhoods until the 1980s, which is the common racial consciousness in majority white neighborhoods even at present. Several members of the [[Ku Klux Klan|KKK]] were active in local politics in the 1920s and 1930s, which was also the case in nearby [[Inglewood, California]] and [[Anaheim, California]] as well. ===Historic Landmarks=== These Torrance landmarks are on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]: * [[Main Building (Torrance High School)]] â ''[[Mediterranean Revival architecture]], 1917 and 1921'' * [[Home Economics Building (Torrance High School)|original Science Buildingâcurrent Home Economics Building (Torrance High School)]] * [[Auditorium (Torrance High School)]] â ''[[Streamline Moderne]], 1938'' * [[Torrance School|Torrance Elementary Schoolâcurrent High School Annex]] â Mediterranean Revival * [[Pacific Electric Railroad Bridge]] â ''designed by
